General Syntax

On this page

Strings ​

Baseline Feature
Version: 0.1.2
Status: ✅ Implemented
Test: 00_base_feats/12_strings.vx

Overview ​

Strings in Vex are UTF-8 encoded text sequences. They are immutable by default and support various operations including comparison, escape sequences, and interpolation.

String Literals ​

Basic Strings ​

Enclosed in double quotes:

rust
let greeting = "Hello, World!";
let name = "Alice";
let empty = "";

Type: string (UTF-8 encoded)
Memory: Heap-allocated with reference counting (smart string system)
Encoding: UTF-8 (supports all Unicode characters)

String Escapes ​

Vex supports standard escape sequences:

SequenceMeaningUnicode
\"Double quoteU+0022
\\BackslashU+005C
\nNewline (LF)U+000A
\rCarriage returnU+000D
\tTabU+0009
\bBackspaceU+0008
\fForm feedU+000C
\uXXXXUnicode (4 hex digits)U+XXXX

Examples:

rust
let newline = "line1\nline2";
let tab = "col1\tcol2\tcol3";
let quote = "He said \"Hello\"";
let path = "C:\\Users\\Admin";
let unicode = "\u0041";  // 'A'
let emoji = "\u263A";    // ☺

Multi-line Strings ​

Use escape sequences for multi-line text:

rust
let poem = "Roses are red,\nViolets are blue,\nVex is fast,\nAnd type-safe too.";

Note: No triple-quoted strings or raw strings in current version.

F-Strings (Interpolation) ​

Formatted strings with embedded expressions, prefixed with f:

rust
let name = "Alice";
let age = 30;
let message = f"Hello, {name}! You are {age} years old.";

let x = 5;
let y = 10;
let result = f"Sum: {x + y}";  // "Sum: 15"

Syntax: f"text {expression} text"

Features:

  • Arbitrary expressions inside {}
  • Type conversion automatic
  • Evaluated at runtime

Examples:

rust
let price = 99.99;
let tax = 0.08;
let total = f"Total: ${price * (1.0 + tax)}";

let count = 42;
let plural = f"Found {count} item{if count != 1 { "s" } else { "" }}";

String Operations ​

Comparison ​

Strings support equality and inequality checks:

rust
let s1 = "hello";
let s2 = "world";
let s3 = "hello";

assert(s1 == s3, "Strings equal");
assert(s1 != s2, "Strings not equal");

// Lexicographic comparison
let a = "apple";
let b = "banana";
assert(a < b, "Lexicographic order");

Operators:

  • == - Equality (compares content)
  • != - Inequality
  • <, <=, >, >= - Lexicographic ordering

Empty String Check ​

rust
let empty = "";
let text = "hello";

if empty == "" {
    print("Empty string");
}

// Using is_empty() method (if available)
// if text.is_empty() { }

String Methods ​

Note: String methods are part of stdlib, not baseline. Current baseline test uses only literals and comparison.

Future methods (planned):

rust
// Length (byte count)
let len = text.len();           // UTF-8 bytes

// Character count
let chars = text.char_count();  // Unicode characters

// Check if empty
let empty = text.is_empty();    // bool

// Case conversion
let upper = text.to_upper();
let lower = text.to_lower();

// Trimming
let trimmed = text.trim();
let left = text.trim_start();
let right = text.trim_end();

// Substring/slicing
let sub = text[0..5];           // Byte slice

// Contains/search
let has = text.contains("ll");  // bool
let pos = text.find("ll");      // Option<i32>

// Split
let parts = text.split(" ");    // Vec<string>

// Replace
let new_str = text.replace("l", "L");

Implementation ​

AST: vex-ast/src/expressions.rs ​

rust
pub enum Expression {
    StringLiteral(String),      // "text"
    FStringLiteral(String),     // f"text {expr}"
    // ...
}

Lexer: vex-lexer/src/lib.rs ​

rust
// String literal parsing
fn read_string(&mut self, is_fstring: bool) -> TokenSpan {
    self.advance(); // skip opening "
    let start = self.position;
    let mut value = String::new();

    while let Some(ch) = self.current_char() {
        if ch == '"' {
            break;
        }
        if ch == '\\' {
            // Handle escape sequences
            self.advance();
            match self.current_char() {
                Some('n') => value.push('\n'),
                Some('t') => value.push('\t'),
                Some('r') => value.push('\r'),
                Some('\\') => value.push('\\'),
                Some('"') => value.push('"'),
                Some('u') => {
                    // Unicode escape: \uXXXX
                    self.advance();
                    let hex = self.read_hex_digits(4);
                    if let Ok(code) = u32::from_str_radix(&hex, 16) {
                        if let Some(ch) = char::from_u32(code) {
                            value.push(ch);
                        }
                    }
                    continue;
                }
                Some(c) => value.push(c),
                None => break,
            }
        } else {
            value.push(ch);
        }
        self.advance();
    }

    if is_fstring {
        Token::FStringLiteral(value)
    } else {
        Token::StringLiteral(value)
    }
}

Codegen: vex-compiler/src/codegen_ast/expressions/literals_expressions.rs ​

rust
Expression::StringLiteral(s) => {
    // Smart string system: Create static string
    // vex_smart_string_t vex_string_static(const char *literal, uint32_t len)

    // Create global string constant in .rodata
    let global_str = self
        .builder
        .build_global_string_ptr(s, "str")
        .map_err(|e| format!("Failed to create string: {}", e))?;

    // Get vex_string_static function from runtime
    let vex_string_static = self.module
        .get_function("vex_string_static")
        .ok_or_else(|| "vex_string_static not found".to_string())?;

    // Call vex_string_static(literal, len)
    let len = self.context.i32_type().const_int(s.len() as u64, false);
    let args = vec![
        global_str.as_pointer_value().into(),
        len.into(),
    ];

    let call_result = self.builder
        .build_call(vex_string_static, &args, "static_str")
        .map_err(|e| format!("Failed to call vex_string_static: {}", e))?;

    Ok(call_result.try_as_basic_value().unwrap_basic())
}

String Representation ​

In memory (smart string):

c
typedef struct {
    char *data;       // UTF-8 bytes
    uint32_t len;     // Byte length
    uint32_t cap;     // Capacity
    uint32_t refcount; // Reference count
    uint8_t flags;    // Static/dynamic flag
} vex_smart_string_t;

LLVM Type:

rust
// Simplified representation
struct string {
    ptr: i8*,    // Pointer to UTF-8 data
    len: i64,    // Length in bytes
}

String Comparison ​

Strings are compared by content (deep comparison):

rust
let s1 = "hello";
let s2 = "hello";
let s3 = "world";

assert(s1 == s2, "Equal strings");  // true (same content)
assert(s1 != s3, "Different");      // true

Implementation: Calls runtime function or inline comparison

rust
// Comparison codegen
fn compile_string_comparison(&mut self, op: &BinaryOp, left: Value, right: Value) {
    match op {
        BinaryOp::Equal => {
            // Call vex_string_eq(left, right) -> bool
            self.build_string_eq_call(left, right)
        }
        BinaryOp::NotEqual => {
            let eq = self.build_string_eq_call(left, right);
            self.builder.build_not(eq, "neq")
        }
        // ... other comparisons
    }
}

F-String Implementation ​

F-strings are parsed and compiled into string concatenation:

rust
let name = "Alice";
let age = 30;
let msg = f"Hello, {name}! Age: {age}";

Lowering (conceptual):

rust
// Internally becomes:
let temp1 = "Hello, ";
let temp2 = name.to_string();
let temp3 = "! Age: ";
let temp4 = age.to_string();
let msg = concat(temp1, temp2, temp3, temp4);

Codegen: compile_fstring() method handles parsing and concatenation

Escape Sequence Processing ​

Lexer: unescape_string() function

rust
fn unescape_string(s: &str) -> String {
    let mut chars = s.chars();
    let mut result = String::new();

    while let Some(ch) = chars.next() {
        if ch == '\\' {
            match chars.next() {
                Some('n') => result.push('\n'),
                Some('r') => result.push('\r'),
                Some('t') => result.push('\t'),
                Some('b') => result.push('\x08'),
                Some('f') => result.push('\x0C'),
                Some('"') => result.push('"'),
                Some('\\') => result.push('\\'),
                Some('u') => {
                    // Unicode: \uXXXX
                    let hex: String = chars.by_ref().take(4).collect();
                    if let Ok(code) = u32::from_str_radix(&hex, 16) {
                        if let Some(unicode_char) = char::from_u32(code) {
                            result.push(unicode_char);
                        }
                    }
                }
                Some(c) => {
                    result.push('\\');
                    result.push(c);
                }
                None => result.push('\\'),
            }
        } else {
            result.push(ch);
        }
    }
    result
}

Examples from Test ​

From Specifications/Tests/00_base_feats/12_strings.vx:

rust
fn main(): i32 {
    // String literals
    let s1 = "hello";
    assert(s1 == "hello", "String literal");

    // String comparison
    let s2 = "world";
    assert(s1 != s2, "String inequality");
    assert(s1 == "hello", "String equality");

    // Empty string
    let empty = "";
    assert(empty == "", "Empty string");

    // String with escapes
    let escaped = "line1\nline2";

    // String concatenation (future feature)
    // let concat = s1 + " " + s2;
    // assert(concat == "hello world", "String concatenation");

    return 0;
}

Limitations ​

Current baseline (v0.1.2):

  • ✅ String literals with escapes
  • ✅ F-string interpolation
  • ✅ String comparison (==, !=)
  • ❌ String concatenation (+ operator)
  • ❌ String methods (len, split, etc.) - Planned for stdlib
  • ❌ Raw strings (r"text\n")
  • ❌ Multi-line string literals
  • ❌ Byte strings (b"data")

Future Features ​

Planned enhancements:

  • String concatenation with + operator
  • String builder for efficient construction
  • Pattern matching on strings
  • Regex support
  • String slicing and indexing
  • More escape sequences (\xHH for hex bytes)
  • Raw string literals (r"C:\path\to\file")

References ​

  • AST Definition: vex-ast/src/expressions.rs
  • Lexer: vex-lexer/src/lib.rs (unescape_string)
  • Codegen: vex-compiler/src/codegen_ast/expressions/literals_expressions.rs (line 338-368)
  • String Methods: vex-compiler/src/codegen_ast/expressions/calls/builtins/string_collections.rs
  • Specification: Specifications/02_Lexical_Structure.md (String Literals section)
  • Test File: Specifications/Tests/00_base_feats/12_strings.vx
